 REPUBLIC OF SIERRA LEONE URBAN WATER SUPPLY PROJECT I. INTRODUCTION 1.I Sierra Leone is endowed with substantial mineral resources, ample cultivable agricultural land and rich fisheries. However, largely as a result of past mismanagement of resources and inadequate development efforts, the majority of its people live in extreme poverty with a per capita income of about US$240 in 1990/91. It is classified as one of the "least developed" countries by the United Nations. Since the late 1970s, Government institutions have deteriorated and have limited capability to deliver even the most basic services. Most infrastructure systems have similarly deteriorated to a point of near collapse. The living conditions for urban residents, particularly in the capital, Freetown, are especially difficult and the quality of life, economic opportunity and environmental conditions are extremely poor. 1.2 In December 1989, to reverse past trends, the Government embarked on a far-reaching reform program, aimed at stabilization and structural adjustment of the economy. Significant reform measures have been successfully implemented, including liberalization of the exchange rate, decontrol of commercial bank lending rates and substantial increases in other interest rates, strengthening of revenue collection and expenditure controls, liberalization of domestic pricing and trade and revamping of natural resources policies. In early 1992, the Government commenced a further program of economic recovery and structural adjustment with the support of international agencies including IDA. 1.3 IDA has actively supported the Government's structural adjustment and economic recovery program through a reconstruction import credit (Cr. 2352-SL) approved by the Board on April 14, 1992. This policy-based credit has helped to restore the Government's capacity to provide essential services and to manage economic reforns. It was followed by two investment credits, the first for the rehabilitation of the power supply and distribution approved by the Board on April 21, 1992 (Cr. 2356-SL) and the second for rehabilitation and maintenance of the roads system approved on December 22, 1992 (Cr. 245 1-SL), and a technical assistance credit (Cr. 2435-SL) approved on November 19, 1992, Freetown Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (FIRP) (Cr. 251 1-SL) approved on June 10, 1993. A Structural Adjustment Credit (Cr. 2546-SL), approved in October 14, 1993, will continue to support the Government's economic reforms and help provide foreign exchange for imports of essential goods and budgetary support for priority public expenditures. 1.4 The Government has requested IDA to finance the proposed project to expand water supply and improve sanitation conditions in Freetown and to undertake watcr supply master plan studies for the major urban centers. The proposed project is a follow up to the FIRP, which provides for improvement of the operations of the Guma Valley Water Company (GVWC) through leak detection and repairs and universal metering program, and financing of studies to update the Water Master Plan and Storm Drainage and Sewerage Master Plan and to review the organization, management and finances of GVWC. Based on the results of thesc studies, the proposed project will improve and modernize the management and operations of GVWC and rehabilitate and expand its water supply systems to meet water demand through year 2005 in Greater Freetown. Furthermore, the project will develop an institutional framework to improve water supply sector operations by carrying out an organization and finance study of the Sierra Leone Water Company (SLWC) and the water supply operations in the othcr major toNvms (including Bo, Kenema, and Makeni) and water master plan studies and designs for these towns. It will also rchabilitate the existing sewerage system and assist in the planning and implementation of low cost sanitation measures in priority areas in Greater Freetown.
 2 II. THE WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION SECTOR A. Water Resources and Sanitation 2.1 Sierra Leone, which lies along the Atlantic seaboard between latitudes 7 and 10 degrees north and longitudes 10 and 13 degrees west, occupies an area of some 72,500 sq km in the bulge of West Africa. To the north a 650km border is shared with Guinea while Liberia provides the boundary along some 250 km to the south. Much of the westem half of the country lies below 200m, rising from mangrove swamps which parallel the coast to the higher and less level ground of the interior lowlands. East of these lowlands the ground again rises to the interior plateau, reaching an altitude of over 900m in the Tungi and Loam mountains and a maximum of 1,950 m in Mount Bintumani, the country's highest peak. 2.2 Climatically the year is divided into well defined dry and wet seasons, the latter of which extends from May to mid-November. In general, mean annual rainfall decreases from an average of some 500cm in the South to under 200cm in the North. Temperatures throughout the year are in the 25-30 degrees centigrade range, the hottest periods being at the beginning and end of the dry season between which the Harmattan wind from the Sahara blows almost daily conveying fine dust which hazes the landscape. The major river systems which traverse the country provide perennial water for agriculture and domestic use. Seasonal rainfall causes variations of up to 18 m in the river levels, the upper reaches are subject to tidal flooding. Most of the rivers are navigable for some miles upstream from the sea and towns have grown from early trading settlements established at their heads of navigation. 2.3 Reticulated drinking water supplies throughout Sierra Leone are almost entirely based on the use of surface sources, the country being adequately served by perennial rivers fed by a high level of annual precipitation'. Traditional sources in the rural areas also rely heavily on surface waters although shallow wells are utilized to a lesser extent and the Government has introduced a shallow well development program. Due to the ready availability of surface water, very little has been done to investigate the extent of underground resources outside Freetown where there are no groundwater resources. 2.4 In rural areas, communities are served primarily by unprotected shallow wells, lakes and rivcrs. Solid and liquid wastes, human and animal excreta all contributable to contaminating ground water sources. Siltation in river beds and lakes caused by mining activities exacerbates the problem for rural communities in search of potable water. The time spent in travelling long distances in search of safe water can be substantial and is time taken away, usually from women, from more productive activitics such as child care2. 2.5 The only public sewers in Sierra Leone are two small ones in Freetown, which are maintained by the Water Supply Division (WSD) of the Department of Energy and Power (DOEP). A study "Master Plan for Wastes in Freetown" in the early 1980s proposed much more extensive sewering but no action has been taken on the recommcndations. Sector Organization 2.6 Before 1961, the (then) Public Works Department was responsible for water supply in Sierra Leone, except for Greater Freetown which was the responsibility of the Freetown City Council. The Guma Valley Water Ordinance 1961 established GVWC with an area of supply of 42 square miles in and around Freetown, and now supplying population of about 0.6 million. Water supply for the remainder of the country became the responsibility of then Ministry of Works until 1974 when it was transferred to the Water Supply Division of the then Ministry of Energy and Power. Following the recommendation of the World Bank Report "Water Supply and Sanitation Study" for Sierra Leone(1983), the Government decided in August 1988 to establish Sierra Leone Water Company (SLWC) to eventually take over responsibility for urban water supplies. As a first phase, SLWC, with some 30 staff, has taken over the water supply operations in the provincial headquarters of Bo and Makeni, with WSD still responsible for Kenema, the District Headquarters of Kodiu/Yengema and other secondary towns, and rural population estimated at 3.4 to 4.4 million. The enabling Act for SLWC, which is still in draft form, will be reviewed as part of the organization, management and finance study financed under the proposed project (para. 2.8) with the view of defining its role in the creation of water companies based on the GVWC operating structure. 2.7 Water supplies outside the GVWC area are regulated by the Water (Control and Supply) Act 1963. This Act apparently envisaged the setting up of one or more independent Water Authorities', each with Board members appointed by a Minister. The Department of Works (DOW) is responsible for drainage. 2.8 To rationalize institutional arrangements for the water supply sector outside Freetown, an institutional, management and finance study for the sector including SLWC, which is responsible for water supply operations in Bo, Kenema and Makeni, will be carried out under the proposed project. The draft TOR for this study has been discussed and agreed with the Government. Agreement has been obtained that this study will be completed by June 30, 1996 and that within three months from the completion of the study, the Government will prepare an action plan to implement the recommendations of the study, as agreed between the Government and IDA. C. Sector Development Stratezy 2.9 The water sector strategy is contained in the draft policy letter prepared by the Government as shown in Annex 2- 1. In common with most sectors of Sierra Leone's economy, the immediate needs in the water supply and sanitation sector are the rehabilitation of existing systems and associated improvements in operation and maintenance. These measures would provide the highest economic return. Rehabilitation would logically be followed by programs of carefully planned expansion and improvement of existing systems to provide acceptable levels of service to a rapidly increasing population. A countrywide water resources plan and groundwater studies would be needed in the longer tern development of the sector. The water master plan studies for the major towns including
 4 Bo, Kenema and Makeni financed under the proposed project will be an important step towards this end. 2.10 The short, medium and long term strategy for GVWC was defined by the IDA-financed GVWC Organization and Financial Review and Water Supply Master Plan studies which were finalized in March - June 1994. The FIRP and the proposed project are, therefore, addressing the short and medium term strategic devclopment of GVWC which is to (a) maximize the supply of water available from existing sources/water systems by minimizing losses/unaccounted-for water and increasing yield of the Guma Reservoir; (b) manage water demand effectively through appropriate tariff policy based on metered consumption; and (c) maximize the efficiency of the water supply operations of GVWC. 2.11 This strategy to maximize water supply to Greater Freetown from existing sources is intended to defer the high long term capital cost (approximately $150 million) of developing the Orugu dam (a new major source of water supply for Greater Freetown) until it becomes essential and consumers would be willing to pay for it. This will provide GVWC with time to consolidate its operational and financial position as a result of investing in the FIRP project and the proposed project. 2.12 Despite economic hardships which beset the country, GVWC has been a remarkably strong and successful organization. At the core of GVWC's success is the financial and operational autonomy granted under its enabling Act. This autonomy has been respected by the Government over the years, as evidenced by a complete lack of government interference. An independent judicial inquiry confirmed in 1993 the operational and financial integrity of GVWC. 2.13 As indicated in paras. 2.6 and 2.8, the institutional management and finance study, to be financed under the proposed project, will recommend the organizational framework for water supply outside Grcater Freetown including the roles of WSD and SLWC. It is envisaged that SLWC would play a key role in developing the water supply systems in the urban towns as well as in establishing water supply utilities for these towns substantially along the GVWC model. 2.14 With respect to sanitation, an initial effort at addressing the health and sanitation conditions in Freetown is being made under the FIRP. FIRP includes slum upgrading, the provision of waste collection and disposal facilities and ablution facilities particularly in the selected low income areas. These efforts would be extended in the proposed project. The proposed project would also rehabilitate the existing small sewage system. These initial steps would maximize benefits from existing facilities and stimulate future development of the Freetown sewerage system. The consultants' report on the "Sewerage and Drainage Master Plan Study," also financed under the FIRP, has recommended, among other things, that the sewerage operations in Freetown be transferred from DOEP to GVWC. It was noted, however, that GVWC will be preoccupied in the next 2 to 3 years with the implementation of the proposed project and the ongoing FIRP, and the reorganization and modernization of the company (para. 4.6). It has been agreed that the sewerage functions in Freetown will be transferred from DOEP to GVWC not later than January 1, 1998, and that an action plan for this transfer will be updated by DOEP/GVWC by January 1, 1997 to be jointly reviewed with IDA. This action plan will also include the transfer of assets and liabilities between the Government and GVWC as well as the sewerage charges to be put in effect by GVWC to ensure that the revenues accrued from the sewerage operations will, at the minimum, be adequate to meet their cash operating expenses and debt service related to the sewerage operations.

Bank Involvement in the Sector 2.15 Bank involvement in the water supply sector began with the preparation of the "Republic of Sierra Leone Water Supply and Sanitation Sector Study" which recommended the creation of SLWC. After a decade-long hiatus, the Bank resumed its involvement through the water supply component of the FIRP approved in June 1993 (Cr. 251 I-SL). The FIRP objectives are to rehabilitate and upgrade essential urban infrastructure and services in Greater Freetown, including the improvement of the water supply capacity of GVWC through a leak detection and repair program and universal metering program and to modernize its financial and operational facilities. The water component of the FIRP is being implemented well and on schedule. The lessons learned from this are that early project preparation, well-planned procurement processing and GVWC's demonstrated management capability are critical factors in successful project implementation These lessons have been incorporated in the design and preparation of the proposed project. The proposed project, which builds upon the water supply component of the FIRP, will develop model(s) for support for water operations in other urban centers, including possible uses of local private management contract services. It will also finance water master plan studies for three major towns which will be the basis for future assistance by external agencies. 2.16 Through IDA involvement under the FIRP, the Government and GVWC have relied on the Bank for advice on water sector policy and institutional development. IDA is also assisting GVWC and the GOSL to examine the management implications of the projected large growth in the investment program and future operation and maintenance needs. The proposed project is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) reviewed by the Board on October 14, 1993. The IDA strategy for Sierra Leone stresses the need to rehabilitate infrastructure, including water systems, and to promote sustainable development by improving the capacity of agencies such as GVWC. Given limitations in the public sector, it recognizes the need for private sector participation in providing many critical social services. The strategy also supports the provision of basic needs such as water supply to poverty groups. III. THE PROJECT A. Project Origin and Formulation 3.1 Following the resumption of Bank operations in Sierra Leone in April 1992, the Bank assisted the Government in preparing an immediate action project to address the unsatisfactory condition of urban infrastructure in Freetown. This resulted in the Freetown Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (FIRP) approved by IDA in June 1993. The FIRP includes, among other things, provisions to improve operations of GVWC through leak detection and repairs, universal metering and computerized billing, and to carry out studies to update GVWC's Water Master Plan and review its organization and finance. The proposed project would be a follow-up to the water supply component of the FIRP and is aimed at continuing to improve the operations of GVWC, to rehabilitate and expand its water supply systems and to improve sewerage and sanitation in Freetown. In February/March 1994, a preappraisal mission visited Sierra Leone to begin the appraisal of the project and its individual sub-components. Project appraisal was carried out jointly with the African Development Fund (ADF) in May/June 1994. In February 1995, since ADF funding was not available as anticipated for the project to move forward, the Government, in consultation with ADF, requested increased IDA financing for the entire project.

BACKGROUND During the first decade after independence in 1961, the economy of Sierra Leone grew at about 4 percent and averaged over 3 percent GDP growth in the first half of the seventies. Thereafter, the economic situation deteriorated sharply and GDP growth slowed down to about 1 percent a year in the period 1975-80. Budgetary revenues fell and major cuts in capital expenditures followed. Investments in social and physical infrastructure and maintenance virtually ceased, causing rapid decay in existing facilities. In 1989, the government adopted a reform program aimed at stabilizing the economy. This included liberalization of the exchange rate and trade, decontrol of prices and interest rates, strengthening of revenue collection and expenditure controls, and a revamping of mining and fisheries policies. Rehabilitation of infrastructure has also begun, with support from IDA and other official multilateral and bilateral agencies.

Deficient water supplies are a serious environmental problem because of their effect on human welfare and economic growth. In Freetown's Kroo Bay area, 30 percent of childhood deaths are caused by diarrhea and 25 percent by malaria both associated with stagnant or polluted water and solid waste contamination. The benefits of target interventions can be measured in terms of reduced medical costs and increased productivity. The revival of the urban economy is essential if urban centers are to serve as the nucleus of growth in the economic recovery of the rural areas and the country as a whole. There has been almost no investment in the water sector for several years due to the economic problems facing the country. The neglect of operations and maintenance of the water infrastructure eroded the existing production capacity and increased the loss of water in the distribution network. The resulting shortages in supply due to dysfunctional systems have created large backlog in demand, over an above the new demand generated by the growth of population and economic recovery. Environmental sanitation (sullage disposal, drainage, human and solid waste management) in urban areas has become a major issue, as urban populations continue to grow at high rates and the need for provision of adequate services becomes more pressing. Management of sanitation is divided up among several agencies although the limits of responsibility are not clearly defined. The key agencies are the ministries responsible for water and health and the Freetown City Council (FCC). Several others play limited roles. 2. There are two main ways in which sullage (kitchen and bath water) currently is disposed of. The majority of owners drain their sullage out into the adjacent pathway where it eventually finds its way into public drains which are often blocked by garbage, weeds and sediment. Other homes tend to dispose of their sullage on site either by surface spreading or in seepage pits. Off site disposal results in ponded water and muddy pathways that make walking difficult and allow mosquitos to breed. Human waste is disposed of by pit latrines and by septic tanks/vaults with soakaways. There is sewerage in only the old central part of Freetown. Garbage is a problem since only a limited collection system has been established. It is generally dumped at official or unofficial sites. Existing water sources are surface waters, a few open wells, standpipes and house connections. Surface waters and well water are usually highly polluted and management of standpipe sites is usually inadequate. Objectives 3. The primary objective of the environmental sanitation component is to reduce possible adverse environmental effects caused by the water which will be brought into the Wellington area of Freetown by the project. In order to achieve this: (i) provision will be made for wastewater disposal and management of new water points; (ii) extension agents will be trained to better promote improved environmental sanitation; (iii) planning activities will be carried out to improve existing domestic sanitation management practices including human waste, sullage disposal, stormwater drainage, and solid waste; and (iv) support will be provided for the organization of neighborhood user groups. The Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) has been carried out to assess the environmental impact of the project which is under Environmental Category B. This report, which is being finalized to take account of the Bank's comments among others, is expected to be made available by the Guma Valley Water Company (GVWC) in Sierra Leone at some public place accessible to affected groups and local NGOs prior to project appraisal. GVWC will officially send it to the Bank to be made available to the Public Information Center (PIC). 2. The EIA addresses the environment impact of the following components of the proposed Urban Water Supply Project: raising of Guma Dam spillway level; diversion of waters from the Little Guma and Upper Sussex catchments into the Guma Dam reservoir; and trunk distribution mains from Congo Cross to Dan Street reservoir and from Africanus Road reservoir to Wellington reservoir. The environmental impact study involved field survey, interviews and discussions with Water Company personnel and local inhabitants by a multidisciplinary team of the consultants Hloward Humphreys & Partners Ltd (UK) in association with Engcon Ltd. (Sierra Leone). The dam site and sites for the construction of weirs, access roads and channels were visited and water samples collected. An analysis of the major issues was made taking cognisance of the factors important to environmental management and resource use. Works to Improve the Yield of Guma Dam 3. Guma dam was constructed in the early 1960's and is situated within the Forest Reserve of the Western Area of Sierra Leone approximately 13 km due south of Freetown. It impounds the Guma River which is one of the rivers forming the upper reaches of No.2 River. About 90% of the annual average inflow to the reservoir occurs in the four months of July to October. The dam is of earth and rockfill construction and is about 70m high. The catchment area is 866 ha and the lake area at a top water level of 261m a.s.l (spillway crest level) is 93 ha. The dam impounds approximately 21 million cubic meters. During construction the forest area upstream of the dam was cleared of vegetation to the 872 ft (266m) contour, which is the same level as the top of the dam. The side channel spillway has been designed for a flood of 210 m3/s. The present spillway could be raised by up to 1.5m and still accommodate the flood without any other work having to be carried out to the dam. 4. The yield of Guma dam can be improved by diverting flows from the adjacent catchments of the Little Guma, Stoney and Water Chute rivers, which form part of the lower Guma/No.2 River catchment. The Upper Sussex catchment of the Sussex river could also be 1/ Source: GVWC - Water Master Plan and Feasibility Study - Possible Immediate Works - Environmental Impact Considerations, January 1994.

In addition, the yield and reliability of Guma can be improved by increasing the storage capacity by raising the spillway level of Guma dam. 5. The lay-out of the Upper Sussex diversion would comprise a 3m high concrete diversion weir at approximately 350m elevation and a trapezoidal unlined channel which would intercept run-off from the various subsidiary catchments. The channel would have a capacity of about 5m3/s which is three times greater than the estimated peak monthly flow in the period 1947 - 1992 of 1.65m3/s. Only a negligible quantity of water will be lost in spills. As with Upper Sussex, it is proposed that diversions from Little Guma should be effected by means of an open channel. The catchment considered comprise three sub-catchments, with approximate areas as follows: Little Guma - 139 ha; Storey river - 47 ha; and Water chute - 42 ha. 6. The findings of the EIA are summarized below: 7. Land Loss and Land Degradation. The catchment areas of the Guma dam, Little Guma, Stoney, Water Chute and Upper Sussex rivers all form part of the Guma Protected Area. The existing catchment for Guma Dam occupies an area of 866 hectares whereas the total area of the four additional sub-catchments is 420 hectares (i.e. Little Guma 139 ha, Upper Sussex 192 ha, Water Chute 42 ha and Stoney 47 ha). The catchments areas are hilly and mountainous and generally unsuitable for agriculture. There is no agricultural or economic activity taking place at present either in the catchments or in the areas proposed for the diversion weirs, channels and access roads. 8. The top water level of the Guma lake is 857 ft (261 m) a.s.l and floods an area of 93 ha. Raising the top water level by 1.5m will increase the dam capacity to about 23 million cubic meters gallons and the flooded area will be increased to 100 ha. At present, the area above top water level is almost free of any significant vegetation. This area constitutes a free board area of 4.5m in depth. Any increase in storage will be accommodated within this area with no need for further vegetation clearing. No significant exposure of land clearing that could facilitate land slip, landslide, serious erosion hazards or land degradation was observed within the catchment areas or in the areas proposed for the diversion weirs, channels or access road. The proposed development areas are devoid of any form of settlement or any form of economic activity. The only major land use is the development works done by Guma Valley Water Company during the construction of the dam and allied components. 9. River Flows. The Guma, Little Guma, Stoney and Water Chute rivers all form part of the upper catchment area of the No. 2 River. There are four more major tributaries further downstream. Due to impoundment by Guma dam, the Guma catchment contributes flow to No. 2 River for no more than three months in the wet season when the dam is spilling. The remaining three catchments are estimated to contribute about 0.3m3/s as an annual average with virtually no flow from January to May. Those people who depend on water from No. 2 River live at the bottom of the catchment. An estimate of discharge at the road bridge near the Forestry Compound Settlement at the end of December 1993 was 90 c.f.s or 2.7m3/s. That part of the Upper Sussex catchment which is likely to feature in any catchment transfer is estimated to have also a mean annual flow of about 0.3m3/s. This is only a very small portion of the total flow in the Sussex River which like No. 2 River is only utilized in its lower reaches. The diversion of water into Guma lake is expected to have little effect on the river regime in the lower reaches.
 -62- Annex 4-7 Page 3 of 6 10. Fish. Aquatic Life and Water Weeds. The lake and rivers are almost free of any algae or water lilies. Mud fish and catfish were observed in the rivers and the Guma lake. Tilapia which has been introduced into the Guma lake were also observed. There was a complete absence of blackflies and snails along the rivers or the lake. 11. Flora and Fauna. The catchment areas are well protected as they lie within the declared Government Forest Reserve. The forest reserve falls under the category of Tropical Moist Evergreen Forest formed on mountains and hill slopes. Presently, the reserves consists of closed high forest, secondary forest and forest regrowth, with relatively high humidity and high annual average rainfall of about 250 inches (6350mm) with 3-4 months of dry season. The forests serve a wide range of ecological functions including the protection and enrichment of the soils and the natural local regulation of the hydrologic cycle especially the flows of surface and groundwater. 12. Animal species found in these forests are: Jonticks Duicker, Diana Monkey, Red Colobus, White-necked Picathartes, Chimpanzee, and a colorful array of insects, bush fowls, reptiles, etc. The forests provide a very rich and wide habitat for these animals. The diversion of the Little Guma and Upper Sussex rivers would have a minimal effect on plant and animal life as less than I % of forest reserve will be affected and also these animals are not sedentary but roam wildly in search of food and shelter. Thus the diversion weirs, channel and access road which will have a width of less than 16m will not limit the free movement of animals nor affect much of the vegetation which is made of forest regrowth, shrub and bush. The clearing will, therefore, not adversely affect the closed high forest as the species are not endangered along the entire channel/access road route which follows approximately the 350m contour. In addition, the very high annual rainfall and average yearly temperature would encourage forest emergence to clothe any of the lands which had been cleared during construction. 13. Health. Observations along the shoreline of the Guma lake and the rivers showed no evidence of snails and blackflies which are intermediate hosts for the transmission of schistomiasis and Onchocerciasis. From interviews it was established that few mosquitoes are present. Guma Valley Water Company workers and inhabitants reported not to have suffered from schists or Oncho, but only from malaria. It is quite likely that the few small ponds in the vicinity of the Guma compound close to the coastal area serves as breeding grounds for mosquitoes. 14. Based on the water quality data and analysis of the water sample collected from Little Guma River and relevant international standards, it can be concluded that the water quality of the rivers to be diverted to the Guma Reservoir will not in any way impair the existing water quality of the Guma Reservoir. 15. Socio-Economic and Socio-Cultural Factors. Interviews carried out with a cross section of the local populace downstream of the dam area with a view of investigating the effect/impact of the construction on the local community revealed that: (i) The immediate community have been availed with the supply of pipe- borne water supply of good quality and of electricity sometime ago.
 -63- Annex 4-7 Page 4 of 6 (ii) The communities downstream have not experienced any serious shortage of their normal water supply needs in areas where pipe-borne water is not available. (iii) Flooding has never been reported. Never has there been any loss of life or property due to any hazard. (iv) No serious erosion, landslides or any form of land degradation has been reported. (v) No water-borne disease or serious health hazard have been reported as a result of the dam. (vi) Agricultural or economic activities are absent in the Guma Reserve. (vii) Degradation is minimal in the immediate environs of the reserve. (viii) There is limited land use and no settlement in the upper and middle catchment areas of the study area. (ix) There is effective restriction entry and regular patrolling of the Guma Reserve. 16. Conclusions and Recommendations. (i) The construction of access road and channel to conduct flows from Little Guma and Upper Sussex catchments to Guma lake will have minimal effect on the land, forest and animal resources of the whole of No. 2 river catchment area as less than 1 % of the catchment area will be disturbed. (ii) By increasing the top water level from 261m to 262.5m a.m.s.l., about 7 ha of additional land surrounding the lake surface will be flooded. This will not entail additional forest clearing as these areas presently form part of the cleared free board of the lake. (iii) The chemical composition of the rivers to be diverted into the Guma lake are very similar to the lake water composition. It is therefore expected that these rivers will not affect the aquatic life of the Guma lake for both fish and plant species. (iv) No inland fishing is carried out in the Guma lake or along the river banks of No. 2 River. Fishing is done only along the coastal creed of the river. (v) There are more major tributaries of No. 2 River downstream of Guma dam. These contribute water to maintain a reasonable flow in the dry season for domestic use and the dilution of water in the mangrove ecology along the coast.
 -64- Annex 4-7 Page 5 of 6 (vi) The Upper Sussex river is not part of the No. 2 River catchment in which the Guma Lake is situated. Diverting water from the Upper Sussex catchment into the Guma lake will not increase the risk of flooding downstream. (vii) Very large flood flows would not be diverted into the Guma. Flow in excess of the carrying capacity of the catchwater channel would continue down the Sussex river. 17. Trunk Distribution Extensions. The proposed project entails the laying of two sections of relatively large diameter pipes (500mm to 700mm diameter) through built-up areas of the city. The first would be from the termination of an existing DN 700 main on Congo Town Main Road to Dan Street reservoir. The length of this main is about 5 km and it will pass through the low cost housing and densely populated area of Kroo Bay as well as the busy commercial section of the city. Engineering considerations preclude any alternative route. The second main, also about 5 km long, would convey water from Africanus Road reservoir to Wellington reservoir. This DN 600 main would be laid in or alongside the Kissy By-pass road. 18. Neither of the two pipelines will have any significant long-term environmental impact. Following construction and reinstatement of all surfaces, the only visible evidence of the pipelines existence will be valve chambers and short sections of exposed pipe where crossing the deeply incised river valleys. Care should be taken when siting pipe fittings to ensure, as far as possible, unobtrusive locations for any chambers, the covers of which should be flush with the road surface or slightly proud on verges. Exposed pipes should be protected against corrosion using bitumen-based paints with colors selected to be unobtrusive and to blend with the surrounds. 19. Major impacts will occur during the construction stage where the route through Freetown's relatively narrow, congested streets will inevitably result in increased noise and traffic disruption. Local traffic control regulations should be enforced and every effort made to minimize disruption by cooperating with the requirements of the local authorities and the traffic police. Access to properties affected by the works should be maintained as far as possible by: (i) limiting the amount of trench permitted to be open at any time; (ii) limiting contractor's stringing operations to avoid long lengths of unlaid pipes strung by the roadside; (iii) providing financial incentives within the contract for prompt temporary reinstatement of trenches; (iv) restricting the dumping of trench spoil in unsuitable or inconvenient locations; and (v) ensuring the provision of adequate road plates to enable trench crossing.

However, the anticipated large quantity of rock to be encountered will mean that jack hammers, rock breakers and possibly even blasting may be required. If so, elaborate measures will need to be taken to safeguard people and property. 21. Traffic control will be a major concern. In the central business district, sufficient alternative routes exist to minimize congestion; however, in the areas of Congo Town, Ascension Town Road, Goderich Road and Kissy Street, significant disruption to traffic must be expected. Well-marked alternative routes are required. Sewerage System Rehabilitation and Extension 22. The extension of the existing sewerage system will have no long term significant adverse environmental impacts. Following the construction of the works the only visible evidence of the extended system will be the manhole covers on the lower sides of the roads carrying the new sewers. These will be flush with the road pavement. New housing structures for the screening facilities within walled compounds will replace the existing structures although the precise locations have yet to be decided. Major impacts will arise from the construction of new sewers in the relatively narrow, heavily congested streets of the central city area in terms particularly of increased noise and traffic disruption. Traffic control measures will be strictly enforced in cooperation with local authorities and the traffic police. Alternative routes will be well marked. Access to private properties and public buildings must be maintained by limiting the length of trench permitted to be open at any time, avoiding storage of pipes in the streets, ensuring that any discharge from dewatering operations, if necessary, is disposed of in an adequate manner, ensuring that trench spoil is not dumped in unsuitable locations, that trenches are (temporarily or permanently) reinstated promptly, that safety barriers and fencing are used and that road plates are provided for trench crossings. Dust and noise will be significant short term impacts but will be mitigated by controlling the contractors' activities, dousing dry surfaces and restricting high noise generating activities in the late evenings. Screening may be necessary to reduce noise and safeguard the public where jack hammers or rock breakers are in use or if blasting is required. 23. An important beneficial impact of the extension works will arise from connecting the eastern part of the system to the main outfall at Government Wharf. This will eliminate the existing outfall in the Naval Base and thus provide improved control over the proposed sewage disposal system. 24. The preferred form of disposal of sewage effluent for Freetown adopted for the project is by means of sea outfalls which discharge offshore and take advantage of the assimilative capacity of the deep waters of the estuary to render the wastes harmless through dilution, dispersion and oxidation. The construction of plastic pipe sea outfalls to serve the immediate requirements of the city will provide significant improvement to the existing conditions of the estuary foreshores. Two outfalls will be constructed to discharge the raw sewage offshore into a depth of water of between 5m and lOm from the sewerage system in the CBD.

doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Urban Water Supply Project are to: 1) improve water supply and sanitation services in Freetown; 2) improve the accessibility of these services to the urban poor; and 3) ensure that water supply and sanitation services will be sustained by strengthening the sectoral institutions. Project components include: a) rehabilitation and repair work on Guma Dam intake tower and raising of the spillway by 1.5m to increase storage; b) refurbishment of the Guma Water Treatment Plant including replacement of obsolete equipment, refurbishment of filters and other modifications to increase capacity to match the supply capacity of the Guma reservoir and transmission pipelines to Freetown; c) construction of new bulk transfer mains to the rapidly growing estern areas of Freetown;d) extensions to the distribution system to meet the projected 2005 demands; e) improvement of reservoirs, and provision of new reservoirs at Governor's Lodge, Kortright and Wilberforce Village; f) refurbishment of the subsidiary at Kongo, including provision of package treatment plant of 1600m/day capacity with the source of raw water from the Kongo Reservoir and replacement of the Old Gloucester Service Reservoirs; g) secondary distribution reinforcement; h) Guma Valley Water Company (GVWC) institutional strengthening; i) supply of computers and vehicles; j) technical assistance to implement computerized systems; k) training of GVWC staff; l) improvement of water supply operations in other major towns; m) sanitation including technical assistance to plan low cost sanitation including the design of a community outreach system involving NGOs and/or other private agencies; and n) rehabilitation and pilot scale extension of the existing sewerage system and extension of the outfalls.
